arch:property.oc:show_val: given a separate locus number because of the a priori knowledge that this section contains a burial underneath the accumulated fill. When the burial was found the locus was shrunk to make new loci for the burial and the area to the south of the burial. The locus thus ended with an area of 1.6 by 1.4 different from the original 2.28 by 2.0
This locus probably should have been finished after the burial was found, but it was continued, which is why L1021 both cuts into and is under the locus.
fine soil, interspersed with hard pebbles, .2 to 2mm
soft in some parts, more hard around the edges

arch:note.arch:string: Contexts excavated in trenches were recorded using the "locus system." A locus is any discrete three-dimensional entity excavated in a trench. The key to the locus system is the recognition that a locus is any one thing. Differences in soil composition or texture are therefore as important as, for example, the difference between a pit and a wall. If two entities were distinct, they were considered separate loci and were therefore assigned separate locus numbers. It should also be noted that every context excavated in a trench was given a locus number and thus the trench itself is made up completely of excavated loci.

oc:metadata.dc:title: Kenan Tepe: Area F / Trench 1 / Locus 1019 (Locus)
